author: chris2_2_2
content: Given that Polygon stays around 30-40gwei despite being a lot smaller than eth and having a lot more capacity it actually makes me wonder how much extra could happen if eth increased block size. Polygon kind of shows that there is no limit to demand if a gas price isn't set. My urban land economics teacher that teaches that widening roads does not decrease traffic would be happy. Kind of pushes the argument that eth should seek to push traffic to l2's/rollups rather then widen the road.

author: potuz
content: I think the analogy of roads and traffic is flawed: if he's trying to make a point about a casual driver having to wait the same amount of time on traffic jams, that may be true. But the point we widen the roads is so that more food gets to the supermarket shelves and more people like the above casual driver can sit on jams and complain

author: chris2_2_2
content:
The idea would be that if more food gets there people will eat more and there will be an increase of people until the same problem exists.

Personally not a fan of that belief but I understand the logic behind it.
